resources.string: Welcome to Five for Five - and thank you for helping to test this app! Over the next few screens, you\'ll see what this app is about and how easy it is to get everything up and going.
Swipe to continue, and hit back at any time to skip the explanation. You can always read this later.

A survey in September 2015 (AAU) found that \23 percent of female undergrads have reported experiencing sexual assault since enrolling in college.\ Another survey (NIJ) found that 1 in 6 American adult women has been the victim of an attempted or completed rape in her lifetime. This means that fewer than 4 out of 5 women live out their lives unmolested.
Four out five isn\'t good enough. We need to push for five.

This app is designed to turn your phone into a discreet trigger you can use to alert your friends in seconds. Just push your power button three times and you\'ve sent a message to a few close people in your life who might be able to help. Some suggestions for when you might want to use this app: Before heading home at night, alert your group to help you if you don\'t check back in; If you see something or someone that seems off, for whatever reason, quietly alert your friends; If you get pulled over and something seems off, discretely let your friends know what\'s happening. Let\'s get started!

First, you\'ll want to set up a group of people you want to alert. Your groups can include as many or as few contacts as you\'d like. Keep in mind that messages are sent individually to each contact, so each person will assume you are sending them a personal text. This makes it more likely for your contacts to respond and help.

To get started, click Manage Contacts from the Welcome screen. You\'ll have one group by default, and can add as many additional groups as you like. We\'ll talk about choosing a default alert group in a few screens.

Next, you\'ll want to set up a message that explains what\'s going on. You can make as many messages as you want, so consider creating an SOS message as well as one to let everyone know you\'re OK. It\'s even faster than checking in on Facebook.
To get started, click Messages from the Welcome screen. You\'ll have one message by default, which you can edit or delete as you like.

You can control which message gets sent to which group in the Settings screen. This is where you\'ll specify how many clicks will trigger the alarm, which message you want to send, and which group to notify. If you want to send a different message to a different group, just click the big \"sound the alarm!\" button on the home screen.
